stimulus:
In this study, you will read text scenarios and make slider judgments about the situations which they describe. Here is an image of an example trial.


In the upcoming trials, please read the descriptions and give your answer by clicking on the slider. Please read each scenario description carefully, but we are interested in your intuitive judgment so no need to second-guess yourself.

You must make a slider judgment in each trial. You will not receive any feedback.


When you are ready to begin, press the start button.

Jo's manager shares their thoughts on a recent company webinar.
Manager: "The webinar on productivity strategies was so enlightening."
Jo: "I thought it was boring. The content didn't really resonate with me."

How boring was the webinar for Jo?

During a coffee break, an Mike notices their colleague looking overwhelmed.
Mike: "You seem really swamped with work lately. I'm concerned that you might be taking on too much."

How concerned is Mike?

Chris's friend Emma asks if you want to join her on a weekend trip:
Emma: "We're planning a spontaneous road trip this weekend. Want to join?"
Chris: "That sounds awesome, but I'm extremely exhausted from traveling all week. I think I need some downtime instead." friend Emma asks if you want to join her on a weekend trip:

How tired is Emma?

During a tech demo, a developer showcases a new app.
Investor: "The features you've included are cutting-edge. It's impressive how you managed to pull this together in such a short time."

How impressive did the investor find the developer's work?

Lisa is working in an open-plan office, but her colleague is having a loud phone conversation nearby.
Lisa: "It's difficult to concentrate with the phone call being that loud. Would you mind lowering your voice a little?"

How difficult is it forLisa to concentrate?

A traveler, Sam, asks an airport staff member where to find a particular gate.
Sam: "Thanks for pointing me in the right direction. You've been helpful."

How helpful did Sam find the staff's help?

Sarah is at a restaurant with friends, but the background music is too loud to have a conversation.
Sarah: "It's quite difficult to talk with the music this loud. Could you ask the staff to turn it down a little?"

How difficult is it for Sarah to talk?

A teacher, Mrs. Carter, is providing feedback on her student's painting.
Mrs. Carter: "This painting is extremely impressive. The colors work really well together, and I can see you've put a lot of thought into the composition."

How impressive did Mrs. Carter think the student's painting was?

A teacher, Mrs. Carter, is providing feedback on her student's painting.
Mrs. Carter: "This painting is impressive. The colors work really well together, and I can see you've put a lot of thought into the composition."

How impressive did Mrs. Carter think the student's painting was?

A sales assistant helps Megan find the exact item she was looking for after searching through multiple aisles.
Megan: "I appreciate your help finding this. You've been helpful."

How helpful did Michael find Rachel's feedback?

Sarah is interning at a company, and her boss, Mr. Thompson asks to stay to finish up her report.
Mr. Thompson: Can you stay late today to help finish up the report?
Sarah: "I'm feeling slightly exhausted after the back-to-back meetings today, so I'm not sure I'd be at my best. Would it be alright if I leave come in early tomorrow to finish it up?"

How tired is Sarah?

Alex is attending a lecture, but a group of students nearby is talking loudly, making it hard to hear the professor.
Alex: "It's extremely difficult to listen to the lecture with all the talking. Could you keep it down, please?"

How difficult is it for Alex to listen to the lecture?

Anna explains why she decided to postpone her vacation to her friend Dan.
Anna: "I think I need to save more money before I can go."
Dan: "That's understandable; budgeting is important."

How understandable does Dan think Anna's reasons are?

Emily: "I'm concerned about Jake; he hasn't been participating in class and seems really withdrawn."

How concerned is Emily?

Sarah excitedly talks about a recent indie band concert she attended with her friend Mark.
Sarah: "I'm so happy I was able to hear them live. I loved every moment!"
Mark: "I thought it was kind of boring. I couldn't get into the music at all."

How boring was the concert for Mark?

Claire is studying for an exam, but her younger siblings are playing noisily in the next room.
Claire: "It's difficult to study with all the noise. Can you please be a bit quieter?"

How difficult is it for Claire to study?

Rachel gives feedback on Michael's draft presentation.
Michael: "I appreciate your suggestions. You've been helpful in improving this."

How helpful did Michael find Rachel's feedback?

Amy's boyfriend Jake wants to talk about their date this weekend, but Amy is tired:
Jake: "Hey, can we talk about this weekend?"
Amy: "I'm exhausted right now. Would it be okay if we talk about it tomorrow instead?"

How tired is Amy?

Lisa: "I noticed my son's grades have dropped significantly, and I'm concerned about how this might affect his future."

How concerned is Lisa?

David: "I thought it was boring. I didn't really understand the art."

How boring were the exhibits for David?

During a group project, Alex helps Jessica by clarifying some confusing instructions.
Jessica: "I appreciate you taking the time to explain that. You've been helpful."

How helpful did Jessica find Alex's help?

Sophie asks Daniel if he can call later tonight:
Sophie: "Can I call you to chat later tonight? I could use some advice."
Daniel: "I'd love to help, but I'm exhausted and might fall asleep. Can we talk tomorrow?"

How tired is Daniel?

Emma's friend, Sarah, needs to cancel their dinner plans because she has a work emergency.
Sarah: "I'm really sorry, but I have to stay late at work tonight. I won't be able to make it to dinner."
Emma: "That's very understandable. Work comes first. We can always reschedule."

How understandable does Emma think Sarah's reasons are?

Ms. Johnson hands back graded essays to her students and gives feedback.
Ms. Johnson: "Your essay was impressive. Well done."

How impressive did Ms. Johnson find the studen's essay?

Sam apologizes to his coworker, Rachel, for missing a call during a meeting.
Sam: "I didn't see your call; I was in a meeting."
Rachel: "That's understandable; we often have back-to-back meetings."
